title: Deuteronomy Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 20.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:1, what should you not be afraid of when going out to battle?
options: Horses, chariots, and a people more than you
questions.correctAnswer: Horses, chariots, and a people more than you
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:1 says not to be afraid when you see horses, chariots, and a people more than you because the LORD your God is with you.

questions.question: Who is commanded to speak to the people when they come near to battle?
questions.correctAnswer: The priest
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:2 states that the priest shall approach and speak unto the people when they come near to battle.

questions.question: What does the priest tell the people not to do in Deuteronomy 20:3?
options: Let their hearts faint, fear, tremble, or be terrified
questions.correctAnswer: Let their hearts faint, fear, tremble, or be terrified
questions.explanation: In Deuteronomy 20:3, the priest commands the people not to let their hearts faint, fear, tremble, or be terrified because they are facing their enemies.

questions.question: Who fights for you against your enemies according to Deuteronomy 20:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD your God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:4 explains that the LORD your God goes with you and fights for you against your enemies.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 20:5, which man is told to return home from battle?
options: He who has built a new house and not dedicated it
He who is the eldest son
questions.correctAnswer: He who has built a new house and not dedicated it
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:5 instructs that a man who has built a new house but has not dedicated it should return home lest he die in battle.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:7, what condition causes a man to be excused from battle?
options: He has betrothed a wife but has not taken her
questions.correctAnswer: He has betrothed a wife but has not taken her
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:7 states that a man who has betrothed a wife but has not taken her should return home to avoid dying in battle.

questions.question: What reason is given in Deuteronomy 20:8 for sending a fearful and fainthearted man home?
options: Lest his brethren's heart faint as well as his
Because he is not a citizen
questions.correctAnswer: Lest his brethren's heart faint as well as his
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:8 says a fearful and fainthearted man should return home so that his fear does not cause others to faint in heart.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 20:10 commands to immediately attack any city you come near without offering peace.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:10 commands to first proclaim peace to the city before attacking it.

questions.question: What happens if a city makes peace with you according to Deuteronomy 20:11?
options: The people become tributaries and serve you
You take all the men captive
questions.correctAnswer: The people become tributaries and serve you
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:11 explains that if the city responds peacefully and opens to you, its people shall be tributaries and serve you.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:13, what must be done to every male in a city that makes war against you?
options: Smite every male with the edge of the sword
questions.correctAnswer: Smite every male with the edge of the sword
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:13 commands to smite every male in the city with the sword after the LORD delivers it into your hands.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Deuteronomy 20:14, the women, little ones, cattle, and all spoil shall be taken unto yourself; and you shall eat the spoil of thine ______, which the LORD thy God hath given thee.
questions.correctAnswer: enemies
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:14 says the spoil of the enemies, including women and children, shall be taken and eaten as given by the LORD.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 20:16 command regarding the cities of the peoples the LORD gives you for an inheritance?
questions.correctAnswer: Save alive nothing that breatheth
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:16 commands to utterly destroy all living things in the cities given as inheritance by the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 20:17 lists the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites as nations to be utterly destroyed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:17 names these specific nations as those to be utterly destroyed as commanded by the LORD.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:19, what should you not destroy when besieging a city for a long time?
questions.correctAnswer: Trees that can be eaten
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:19 commands not to destroy trees by forcing an axe against them because they provide food and life.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 20:20 allows cutting down any trees during a siege regardless of their use.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:20 says only trees not for food should be cut down to build siege works.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing fear before a difficult challenge. Based on Deuteronomy 20, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: Do not be afraid because the LORD your God goes with you to fight for you
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored
Rely on your own strength because God expects you to be brave
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be afraid because the LORD your God goes with you to fight for you
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:1 and 20:4 teach that God is with His people and fights for them, encouraging believers not to fear even when facing overwhelming opposition.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 20 instruct leaders to encourage those preparing for spiritual or life battles?
options: Priests should speak to the people, urging them to not faint or fear
Leaders should threaten punishment for fearfulness
Encourage only the strongest to fight, ignoring the fearful
questions.correctAnswer: Priests should speak to the people, urging them to not faint or fear
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:2-3 shows that priests are to encourage Israel not to let their hearts faint or be terrified, teaching reliance on God’s presence.

questions.question: A man has recently built a new house but not dedicated it yet. Based on Deuteronomy 20, what guidance is given about going into battle?
options: He should return home lest he die and someone else dedicate the house
He must fight regardless of his new house
He should sell the house before going to battle
He is exempt from battle because of his new house
questions.correctAnswer: He should return home lest he die and someone else dedicate the house
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:5 advises that a man who has built but not dedicated a house should return home to preserve his inheritance, emphasizing prudence and stewardship.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20, what should a man do if he has betrothed a wife but not yet taken her when called to battle?
options: He should return home to avoid losing his bride
He must go to battle regardless
He can send a substitute in his place
He should postpone the marriage indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: He should return home to avoid losing his bride
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:7 instructs such men to return home lest they die in battle and another man take their bride, highlighting respect for family and marriage commitment.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 20 teach about the role of fearfulness among soldiers?
options: Fearful and fainthearted men should return home to prevent discouragement
Fearful men should be forced to fight
Fearfulness is a virtue to be honored
There is no mention of fear in this context
questions.correctAnswer: Fearful and fainthearted men should return home to prevent discouragement
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:8 directs that fearful men return home to avoid causing their brethren to faint, showing the importance of courage and morale in community.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 20 guide believers about fighting against a city that offers peace?
options: Accept peace and make its people tributaries
Ignore peace and besiege the city
questions.correctAnswer: Accept peace and make its people tributaries
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:10-11 instructs that if a city offers peace, it should be accepted and the people become tributaries, teaching mercy and wise conflict resolution.

questions.question: What is the biblical principle about stewardship and destruction taught in Deuteronomy 20 concerning trees during a siege?
options: Do not destroy fruit trees as they provide life and sustenance
Cut down all trees to build siege works
Destroy all trees regardless of type
Trees are irrelevant in battle and can be used freely
questions.correctAnswer: Do not destroy fruit trees as they provide life and sustenance
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:19 teaches not to destroy fruit trees during a siege because the tree of the field is man’s life, emphasizing care for provision and creation.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 20, God commands utter destruction of the inhabitants of the cities given as an inheritance to Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:16-17 states that nothing that breathes should be saved in the cities given as inheritance, showing God’s command for total destruction to avoid sin.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 20 instructs that women and children should be killed in every battle.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:14 clarifies that women, children, cattle, and spoil should be taken as plunder, not killed, except in specific commanded cases.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 20 teach about leadership selection in times of trial or battle?
options: Officers appoint captains to lead after speaking to the people
Leaders are chosen by popular vote
Only elders lead without formal appointment
There is no mention of leadership selection
questions.correctAnswer: Officers appoint captains to lead after speaking to the people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:9 shows that after encouragement, officers appoint captains to lead, highlighting orderly leadership and organization during challenges.

questions.question: A believer is feeling exhausted and discouraged in their spiritual walk. Based on Deuteronomy 20, what counsel about perseverance and community would you share?
options: Encourage those fainthearted to step back to strengthen the whole community
Ignore discouragement and push through alone
Leave the community if feeling weak
questions.correctAnswer: Encourage those fainthearted to step back to strengthen the whole community
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:8 teaches that fearful and fainthearted should return home so their weakness does not discourage others, illustrating wise community care and perseverance.

questions.question: What principle about marriage and family responsibility is taught in Deuteronomy 20?
options: Men who have betrothed wives should return home from battle to protect their family rights
Marriage is secondary to warfare and must be postponed
Families should be left behind without protection
Marriage does not affect wartime duties
questions.correctAnswer: Men who have betrothed wives should return home from battle to protect their family rights
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:7 instructs men with betrothed wives to return home, showing the importance of honoring family commitments and protecting marriage.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 20 instruct believers to act with integrity and obedience in war?
options: Carry out God’s commands fully, including destruction of enemy nations as instructed
Modify commands based on personal judgement
Spare enemies to show mercy regardless of God’s command
questions.correctAnswer: Carry out God’s commands fully, including destruction of enemy nations as instructed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:17-18 emphasizes obedience to God’s command to utterly destroy certain nations to avoid adopting their sinful practices.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 20 teaches that the tree of the field is man's _____.
questions.correctAnswer: life
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:19 states that the tree of the field is man’s life, teaching the value of sustaining life and provision even during conflict.

questions.question: How should believers view God’s presence in trials, according to Deuteronomy 20?
options: God is with us and fights for us, so we should not fear
God abandons us in battle, so we must rely on ourselves
God is neutral and does not intervene
Victory depends solely on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God is with us and fights for us, so we should not fear
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:1 and 20:4 affirm that God is present and fights for His people, encouraging faith and trust in His power during trials.

questions.question: What lesson about stewardship and blessing can be drawn from the instruction regarding vineyards in Deuteronomy 20?
options: A man who has planted a vineyard but not eaten its fruit should return home to safeguard his blessing
Vineyards should be neglected during times of war
Fruitless vineyards are to be destroyed immediately
Planting a vineyard has no relevance to battle
questions.correctAnswer: A man who has planted a vineyard but not eaten its fruit should return home to safeguard his blessing
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:6 advises men to return home if they have not yet enjoyed the fruit of their vineyard, teaching care for God-given blessings and family welfare.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 20.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:1, what reason is given for Israel not to fear enemies with horses and chariots?
options: The LORD thy God is with thee
They will flee at your approach
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD thy God is with thee
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:1 states that the reason not to fear is because the LORD thy God is with thee, who brought you out of Egypt.

questions.question: In the battle preparation in Deuteronomy 20, who approaches the people to encourage them before battle?
questions.correctAnswer: The priest
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:2 describes the priest approaching the people to speak and encourage them before battle.

questions.question: What is the main theme of the priest's speech to the people in Deuteronomy 20:3-4?
options: Do not be afraid because God fights for you
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be afraid because God fights for you
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 emphasize not fearing the enemy because the LORD your God goes with you to fight and save you.

questions.question: Which of the following would cause a man to be sent home from battle according to Deuteronomy 20:5-7?
options: He has built a new house and not dedicated it
questions.correctAnswer: He has built a new house and not dedicated it
questions.explanation: Verse 5 specifically mentions men who have built new houses but have not dedicated them are allowed to return home so they may not die in battle.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 20:6 instructs which men to return home from battle?
options: Those who have planted a vineyard and not yet eaten its fruit
Those who are untrained in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Those who have planted a vineyard and not yet eaten its fruit
questions.explanation: Verse 6 requires men who planted vineyards but have not yet enjoyed their fruit to return home to avoid dying before enjoying their labor.

questions.question: What reason does Deuteronomy 20:8 give for allowing fearful and fainthearted men to return home?
options: Lest their brethren's heart faint as well
Because they are unfit for battle
Because they must guard the city
questions.correctAnswer: Lest their brethren's heart faint as well
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains that fearful men should return home so their fear does not weaken the morale of their fellow soldiers.

questions.question: What is the first action to take when approaching a city to fight against it, according to Deuteronomy 20:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaim peace to the city
questions.explanation: Verse 10 commands that you first offer terms of peace to the city before beginning hostilities.

questions.question: If the city accepts the offer of peace in Deuteronomy 20:11, what is the status of the people within it?
options: They become tributaries and serve you
They are allowed to keep their weapons
They are expelled from the city
questions.correctAnswer: They become tributaries and serve you
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states that if the city accepts peace, its inhabitants become tributaries and serve the Israelites.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:13-14, what is the fate of the men and the women in a city taken by war?
options: Men are killed, women and little ones are taken as spoil
All men and women are killed
Men are enslaved, women are spared
Men are spared, women are killed
questions.correctAnswer: Men are killed, women and little ones are taken as spoil
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 14 instruct killing every male but taking women, children, cattle, and spoil for oneself.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 20:16-17 commands complete destruction of which groups?
options: The Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites
questions.correctAnswer: The Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 list these specific peoples to be utterly destroyed as commanded by God.

questions.question: What is the stated purpose in Deuteronomy 20:18 for destroying the nations given as inheritance to Israel?
options: So they do not teach Israel to follow their abominations
To gain their land for farming
questions.correctAnswer: So they do not teach Israel to follow their abominations
questions.explanation: Verse 18 explains the destruction is to prevent Israel from adopting the sinful practices of these nations.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:19, what instruction is given regarding trees during a long siege?
options: Do not destroy fruit trees because they provide food
Cut down all trees to build siege weapons
questions.correctAnswer: Do not destroy fruit trees because they provide food
questions.explanation: Verse 19 prohibits cutting down fruit trees during a siege since the tree of the field is life and provides food.

questions.question: Which trees does Deuteronomy 20:20 allow to be cut down during a siege?
questions.correctAnswer: Trees not for food
questions.explanation: Verse 20 permits cutting down only those trees known not to be fruit-bearing to build siege works.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 20 instructs that men who have newly betrothed a wife but not taken her should be allowed to go to battle.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 7 instructs men betrothed but not married to return home lest they die in battle and another man take their wife.

questions.question: True or False: The officers in Deuteronomy 20 are responsible for appointing captains after addressing the people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states that after speaking to the people, officers shall appoint captains to lead the armies.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:1, what is the reason the Israelites should not fear when facing enemies with horses and chariots?
options: The LORD thy God is with thee, who brought thee out of Egypt
They are fighting on home territory
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD thy God is with thee, who brought thee out of Egypt
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 20:1 emphasizes that the presence of God who delivered Israel from Egypt is the basis for courage, consistent with Exodus 14:13-14 where Moses tells Israel not to fear because God will fight for them, and Joshua 1:9 where God commands not to be afraid for He is with them.

questions.question: What role does the priest have before the battle as described in Deuteronomy 20:2-3?
options: To encourage the people not to fear
questions.correctAnswer: To encourage the people not to fear
questions.explanation: Verses 2 and 3 show the priest speaking to the people to strengthen their hearts not to fear, reflecting the biblical role of priests as spiritual leaders who encourage trust in God (cf. 1 Samuel 12:23, Psalm 27:1).

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 20:4, what specific attribute of God is highlighted concerning Israel’s battle?
options: God fights for Israel and saves them
God punishes Israel if they lose
questions.correctAnswer: God fights for Israel and saves them
questions.explanation: Verse 4 declares God's active role in fighting for Israel and delivering them, showing His attribute as a divine warrior and savior, consistent with Exodus 15:3 and Psalm 44:3.

questions.question: Which individuals were allowed to return home instead of joining the battle, according to Deuteronomy 20:5-7?
options: Those who built a new house, planted a vineyard, or betrothed a wife
Those who were elderly or weak
Those who were priests or Levites
questions.correctAnswer: Those who built a new house, planted a vineyard, or betrothed a wife
questions.explanation: Verses 5-7 instruct officers to allow men with new houses, vineyards, or betrothed wives to return home, showing concern for family and property responsibilities, emphasizing the value of life and legacy (cf. Ruth 1:11-13, Ecclesiastes 3:1-8).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:8, why should fearful and fainthearted men be sent home?
options: Because their fear could discourage others
Because they are unfit to fight physically
questions.correctAnswer: Because their fear could discourage others
questions.explanation: Verse 8 explains that fearful men should return to prevent their fear from weakening the hearts of their brethren, highlighting the importance of morale in communal faith and obedience (cf. Numbers 13:31-33, Joshua 1:6-7).

questions.question: What is the first action Israel must take when approaching a city to fight, as commanded in Deuteronomy 20:10?
options: Destroy the crops surrounding the city
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaim peace to the city
questions.explanation: Verse 10 directs Israel to offer peace first, demonstrating God’s desire for reconciliation before judgment (cf. Ezekiel 33:11, Matthew 5:9).

questions.question: What happens if a city accepts the offer of peace, according to Deuteronomy 20:11?
options: The inhabitants become tributaries and serve the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: The inhabitants become tributaries and serve the Israelites
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states those who accept peace become tributaries and serve Israel, reflecting God’s provision for subjugation without destruction (cf. 1 Samuel 10:2, Jeremiah 27:6).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:13-14, what is the treatment of men and non-combatants when a city is taken by war?
options: All males are killed; women, children, and spoil are taken as plunder
questions.correctAnswer: All males are killed; women, children, and spoil are taken as plunder
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 command the killing of all males but sparing women and children as spoils, reflecting ancient warfare practices and God's justice in judgment (cf. Joshua 6:21, 1 Samuel 15:3).

questions.question: What distinction does Deuteronomy 20:15-17 make about cities near Israel versus distant cities?
options: Distant cities may have survivors spared; cities of the inherited nations must be utterly destroyed
All cities are treated the same
Only cities with walls are destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: Distant cities may have survivors spared; cities of the inherited nations must be utterly destroyed
questions.explanation: Verses 15-17 show a difference: distant cities are treated with some mercy, but the nations occupying the land God gave Israel must be completely destroyed to avoid idolatry (cf. Exodus 23:23-33, Joshua 10:40).

questions.question: Why does God command the destruction of certain nations in Deuteronomy 20:18?
options: To prevent Israel from imitating their abominations and sinning against God
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent Israel from imitating their abominations and sinning against God
questions.explanation: Verse 18 reveals the theological reason: it is to stop Israel from adopting idolatry and sinful practices of these nations, showing God’s holiness and desire for His people’s purity (cf. Leviticus 18:24-30, 2 Corinthians 6:14-18).

questions.question: What instructions does Deuteronomy 20:19 give concerning trees during a siege?
options: Do not destroy fruit trees as they provide food and represent life
Cut down all trees for siege works
Burn the trees to intimidate the city
questions.correctAnswer: Do not destroy fruit trees as they provide food and represent life
questions.explanation: Verse 19 forbids destroying fruit trees during siege because they sustain life, reflecting God’s provision and respect for creation (cf. Jeremiah 17:7-8, Psalm 1:3).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 20:20, which trees are permitted to be cut down during a siege?
options: Only trees not used for food
questions.correctAnswer: Only trees not used for food
questions.explanation: Verse 20 permits cutting down only those trees that do not bear food, emphasizing stewardship even in war (cf. Isaiah 10:34, Ezekiel 31:4).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 20:9 describe the leadership structure after the officers finish speaking to the people?
options: They appoint captains of armies to lead
questions.correctAnswer: They appoint captains of armies to lead
questions.explanation: Verse 9 indicates the officers appoint captains to lead the people, showing God’s order and structure in warfare, paralleling 1 Samuel 9:16 and Hebrews 13:17 about leadership.

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s presence is emphasized repeatedly in Deuteronomy 20:1-4?
options: God is a present warrior who fights for His people
God is distant and uninvolved in battles
God only allows natural causes to win wars
God punishes Israel when they fight
questions.correctAnswer: God is a present warrior who fights for His people
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 affirm God’s active presence and fighting on behalf of Israel, consistent with Exodus 15:3 and Psalm 24:8, revealing His attribute as a divine warrior and protector.

questions.question: What principle about fear and courage is taught in the battle exhortation of Deuteronomy 20:3-4?
options: Do not fear or become faint because God fights for you
Courage depends solely on human strength
Fear is inevitable and must be accepted
Only the strongest warriors should fight
questions.correctAnswer: Do not fear or become faint because God fights for you
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 teach trust in God’s presence as the basis for courage, agreeing with New Testament exhortations like 2 Timothy 1:7 and Hebrews 13:6 about God’s power overcoming fear.

questions.question: How does the command in Deuteronomy 20:16-17 to utterly destroy certain peoples relate to God’s holiness and justice?
options: It prevents the corruption of Israel by idolatry and sin
It is arbitrary destruction without reason
It shows God’s favoritism without justice
It is a temporary military tactic only
questions.correctAnswer: It prevents the corruption of Israel by idolatry and sin
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 show God’s judgment to uphold holiness by eradicating sinful nations, preventing Israel’s spiritual downfall, consistent with Leviticus 20:22-26 and Romans 12:1-2.
